dc:title: Territory selection in a desert grasshopper: the maximization of conversion efficiency on a chemically defended shrub
dc:creator: Greenfield M.D.
dc:description: Ligurotettix coquilletti (Acrididae: Gomphocerinae) is an oligophagous grasshopper found mostly on creosote bush Larrea tridentata in the deserts of SW North America. Adult males defend individual host-plants as mating territories. Preferred shrubs, used as territories each year, are distinguished by low concentrations of the phenolic compound nordihydroguaiaretic acid. Adult males suffered high mortality on "avoided' shrubs due to starvation and consequent desiccation. Mortality of females did not differ between preferred and "avoided' shrubs, but between 7-14 days post-eclosion females grew at significantly slower rates on avoided shrubs. The low growth rates of females on avoided shrubs were attributable to low conversion rates of digested food. Adult males that survived on "avoided' shrubs, and both male and female nymphs, showed similar reduction in conversion rates of digested food. Certain substances in the foliage of "avoided' Larrea shrubs presumably have a toxic effect on metabolic processes in L. coquilletti. Variation in host-plant quality had both a direct effect on the growth of male L. coquilletti and an indirect effect on their expected encounter rates with females. Consequently, a high degree of inter-male competition occurs over the territorial ownership of preferred shrubs. -from Authors

dc:title: Resource utilization and territoriality in group-living capybaras (Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris)
dc:creator: Herrera E.
dc:description: Groups of capybaras living in the seasonally flooded savannas of Venezuela showed seasonal shifts in habitat use in relation to changes in availability of favourable habitat (mainly grassland) caused by the alternation of drought and flooding. Group home-ranges were stable; certain activities (eg resting, grazing, wallowing) were largely restricted to specific localities within each range. Although groups fed on the most favourable habitat in relation to its availability, individuals fed for similar amounts of time in this habitat irrespective of its availability per head. Groups of capybaras were territorial. Territory size varied between 5-16 ha (10.4±3.7 ha) and was positively correlated with group size. All home-ranges (1 exception) had a section of each of 4 major habitat types. The areas of 2 of these habitat types (bush scrub and low-lying grassy patches) correlated significantly with group size. The area of bushy scrub in each home-range correlated with the reproductive success of females occupying it. These 2 habitats are essential for survival in the dry season (grassy patches) and wet season (bushy scrub). Capybaras depend upon access to permanent surface water. Where there is such water, territories are configured to encompass sufficient resources to ensure survival under widely different seasonal conditions. -from Authors

dc:title: Survival of eggs in the gypsy moth Lymantria dispar. II. Oviposition site selection in changing environments
dc:creator: Higashiura Y.
dc:description: Geographical variation in oviposition site of the gypsy moth was studied in 5 regions in Japan. Eggs were laid in tree canopies in the regions without snow, but both above and beneath the snow in snowy regions. In snowy regions, oviposition sites beneath the snow had the benefit of producing higher egg mass survival only under high levels of avian predation. Predation pressure on egg masses created unpredictably changing oviposition environments for females, which deposit only one mass in summer. A simple model, based on the Levins fitness set approach, is described for anlysing the pattern of geographical variation. The new approach to oviposiiton site selection focuses away from the use of instantaneous fitness values as a measure of adaptiveness and towards the use of long-term fitness values measured in unpredictably changing environments. Females seemed to have the same probability of oviposition above the snow in each regional population. Avian predation was regarded as a selective mechanism in the oviposition behaviour of the gypsy moth. -from Author

dc:title: Movement patterns and morphometrics in giant tortoises
dc:creator: Swingland I.
dc:description: Intraspecific differences in movement and body shape in Aldabran tortoises Geochelone gigantea were investigated. Individuals are generally faithful to a particular movement pattern; individuals which migrate to the coast are longer and narrower than those that are relatively sedentary; and individuals of both shapes die inland but only those that are shorter and wider die on the coast. These latter animals are all near the age of sexual maturity (c23 yr). The proportion of migratory tortoises changes with age; the proportion of migrators in the older and young/immature age groups appearing higher than in middle-aged groups. Males migrate to the coast in proportionally larger numbers. Although we cannot distinguish differences in shell shape in immature tortoises, which migrate in quite significant numbers, such differences are apparent in older animals. Shape differences are probably principally associated with the influence of habitat (or lifetime track) rather than simply a function of age. There are 4 possible models which may explain a system controlling the determination of an individual's movement pattern: a mixed strategy within an individual (an individual mixed strategy), a mixed strategy within a population (a genetic polymorphism), a conditional strategy or a learnt movement pattern. -from Authors

dc:title: Food quality for detritivores in streams of contrasting pH
dc:creator: Groom A.
dc:description: Leaves of alder Alnus glutinosa and beech Fagus sylvatica were conditioned in an acid and a circumneutral stream. Respiration rate of microbes on leaf surfaces conditioned in circumneutral water was greater than on those from acid water for the first 8-16 days of exposure in the same stream; this corresponded to differences in microbial biomass. C:N ratios were lower in the neutral conditioned leaves of both species. For alder, differences due to leaf conditioning persisted for c14 days of exposure in the same stream. Aluminium, scarce at first, accumulated markedly on all leaves during conditioning. During further exposure Al content increased in alder only, the rate being greater in the acid stream. Invertebrate animals colonized the leaf bags in both streams, although erratically in the circumneutral stream. In the acid stream, there was faster colonization of neutral than there was of acid-conditioned alder over the first 8 days of exposure. Feeding on acid or neutral-conditioned leaves of both species produced no significant difference in growth of the caddis Lepidostoma hirtum but the stonefly Nemurella pictetii grew faster on neutral-conditioned litter. Reduction in food quality could account for the reduced productivity of acid streams, and also for some of the differences in their invertebrate species composition, but the distribution of N. pictetii is not due to food quality. -from Authors

dc:title: Serial effects of host infestation on egg allocation by the Mediterranean fruit fly: a rule of thumb and its functional significance
dc:creator: Papaj D.
dc:description: Prior infestation of host kumquats Fortunella japonica with the eggs of Ceratitis capitata had a number of effects on the oviposition behaviour of conspecific flies. Overall, infestation markedly reduced the rate at which clutches were laid by a female searching within a host tree. Egg infestation decreased the probability that a female 1) bored with her ovipositor after landing on a fruit and 2) deposited a clutch once oviposition-boring was initiated, and 3) deposited additional clutches at new sites on the fruit before leaving. Egg infestation also decreased duration of an oviposition (and thus probably clutch size) and tended to decrease the persistence with which a female foraged on fruit. Infestation had no effect on the persistence with which a female foraged within a tree or on the rate at which a female landed on fruit. A simple rule of thumb for response by Mediterranean fruit flies to egg infestation is presented. This rule implies that different foraging traits such as clutch size and giving up time are mechanistically related and should not be treated independently in foraging theory. Both survival to pupation and the expected fecundity of survivors decreased progressively as egg density in host fruit was artificially increased, suggesting that progeny deposited in egg-infested fruit have lower fitness than progeny deposited in uninfested fruit. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific life-history variation in Lymnaea peregra (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). I. Field study
dc:creator: Lam P.
dc:description: By comparing the dynamics of 3 neighbouring populations (Sheaf, Rivelin and Don) of Lymnaea peregra, the extent to which interpopulation differences in life history are due to environmental factors was examined. The Don population started breeding earlier, and had longer breeding seasons than the Sheaf and Rivelin populations. The Sheaf population was bivoltine while the Rivelin and Don populations were univoltine. Members of the summer cohort of the Sheaf population had higher growth rates and reproductive outputs. Sheaf and Rivelin snails had higher mortality rates than Don snails in winter. Lower temperatures and faster currents accounted for the higher mortality rates at the Sheaf and Rivelin sites. Food availability was important for growth rates and number of breeding bouts per year. -from Authors

dc:title: A model of population dynamics for the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster with density dependence in more than one life stage and delayed density effects
dc:creator: Rodriguez D.
dc:description: Pre-adult survival decreased with pre-adult density. Adult fecundity decreased with both pre-adult density and adult crowding. These effects were used to construct a model of density-dependent population dynamics, which predicts the number of pre-adults for each generation in a population with 2 life stages and non-overlapping generations. Populations of small size and non-overlapping generations were maintained for 9 generations. Numbers of eggs and adults showed sustained, erratic fluctuations. A deterministic version of the dynamical model predicts rapid approach to equilibrium and cannot explain such fluctuations. Predictions of a stochastic version of the dynamical model, however, agree with the observed behaviour of the experimental populations. Oscillations in numbers are interpreted as a consequence of random fluctuations. -from Author

dc:title: Population regulation in the wood mouse, Apodemus sylvaticus. I. Density dependence in the annual cycle of abundance
dc:creator: Montgomery W.
dc:description: The annual dynamics of Apodemus sylvaticus in woodland were remarkably consistent with numbers decreasing in spring, remaining relatively stable during early summer, and increasing in late summer and autumn, in 87%, 71% and 88% of the available data, respectively. Stability in population size in summer was produced by low densities. Instantaneous rate of population change per week was negatively correlated with initial population size during periods when numbers normally increased. Density dependence accounted for up to 61% of variation in instantaneous rate of population change. Intrinsic mechanisms contributing to this effect are likely to include variation in rates of reproduction and dispersal with density of overwintered males and females. Following greater peak abundance the rate of decline over winter was less severe, atrributable to the positive influence of increased food supply on abundance in autumn and early winter and survival of mice over winter. There was no evidence of density dependence in the chronology of the termination of the spring decline or the onset of autumn increase. The end of the autumn increase was negatively related to initial autumn density, ie peak abundance was later following lower densities in late summer. Density-dependent effects during the increase phase of the annual cycle are sufficient to regulate population size by promoting population recovery from very low summer densities and limiting peak abundance in early winter. In years of maximum seed production, however, density dependence may be overridden. -from Author

dc:title: Individual differences, parasites, and the costs of reproduction for bighorn ewes (Ovis canadensis)
dc:creator: Festa-Bianchet M.
dc:description: In SW Alberta, ewes that raised sons did not experience a decrease in reproductive sucess the following year, but their faecal output of lungworm (Protostrongylus spp.) larvae increased relative to ewes that raised daughters. Ewes were seldon known to produce sons in consecutive years. This result could be explained by either an alteration of the birth sex ratio, or differential mortality of sons born in the year after their mother had produced a son. Ewes that lactated at 2yr of age appeared to be in better condition, and were more likely to lactate at 3 yr of age, than ewes that did not lactate at 2 yr. Overall, reproductive success in one year did not aversely affect reproduction the following year. Lactating ewes had greater faecal counts of lungworm larvae than non-lactating ewes. Ewes that had produced a lamb at 2 yr of age were more likely to diet during a pneumonia epizootic that ewes that had not lambed at 2 yr. A decrease in resistance to parasites and pathogens appears to be a consequence of reproduction. -from Author

dc:title: Ecology: where genes and geography meet. Presidential address to the British Ecological Society, December 1988
dc:creator: Berry R.
dc:description: The detection and analysis of pattern has long been a major preoccupation of ecologists, and significant advances in understanding have resulted, but many patterns reduce to little more than the effect of fairly trivial ordering processes operating on randomness. There is a sense in which ecological succession is simply an expression of island biogeography, or vice versa. Opportunism is probably much more important in natural systems than is generally appreciated. It is clearly manifest in colonization and founder differentiation; it is just as important in selection response (eg when disease or climatic stress strikes). Optimization theory has contributed to a better understanding of many ecological areas, eg life-history theory and, feeding strategy, but needs generalizing to include the overall concept of biotic interactions with habitat templets. All organism-habitat interactions are dependent on genetic factors, and can be modified by genetic change. Although it is possible to derive complex coevolutionary models, it is simpler and perhaps more useful to regard all such interactions as straightforward gene-environment ones. Four landmarks to guide our dissection are: faith that general principles can be deduced and that we are not inevitably subject to an inchoate morass of data; that ability to make predictions is not necessarily the only proper goal in ecology; that ecology is an "unrestricted science', and we neglect variation at our peril; but above all, a recognition that ecology, like evolutionary biology, is a synthesis of disciplines. -from Author

dc:title: Long-term decline in fecundity in a snow goose population: evidence for density dependence?
dc:creator: Cooch E.
dc:description: A population of lesser snow goose Chen caerulescens caerulescens has been studied at the breeding colony at La Perouse Bay, Manitoba. Annual mean clutch size, adjusted for annual variation in mean laying data and intraspecific nest parasitism, has declined significantly by 0.72 eggs, or 16% of the initial annual mean, from 1968 to the present. Annual rates of egg loss due to predation, egg hatchability, and fledging success have remained unchanged. The rate of the long-term decline in mean clutch size was independent of female age and breeding experience, and was not related to systematic changes in the age structure of the breeding population. Individual females had clutch size declines parallel to the decline of the population mean. Mean clutch size is negatively correlated with the size of both the breeding colony and the total flyway population, both of which have increased significantly. The decline in clutch size may reflect increased intraspecific competition for food during spring migration. -Authors

dc:title: Spatial distribution of defence and foraging in young-of-the-year brook charr, Salvelinus fontinalis
dc:creator: Grant J.
dc:description: Brook charr in running water typically hold position at a central place and feed on drift, often within a defended territory. In streams near Guelph, Ontario, frequency of aggressive acts and mean aggressive radius (upstream = 2.7 body lengths, downstream = 1.6 body lengths) were greater upstream than downstream of the central place, consistent with the hypothesis that brook charr defend their access to drift by excluding fish upstream of their position. Maximum lateral aggressive radius (3.5 body lengths) was not significantly different from the maximum lateral foraging radius (3.9 body lengths), but mean lateral aggressive radius (2.3 body lengths) was greater than the mean lateral foraging radius (1.3 body lengths). Therefore, the maximum widths of the defended and foraging areas were similar but the relative use of this space for defence and foraging was different. Fish with wider defended areas had wider foraging areas. Most foraging attempts directed at drift were downstream of the central place; this tendency increased with increasing current velocity. Detecting suitable drifting prey appeared to become more difficult in faster water currents. Mean and maximum foraging radius were proportional to L1.00 (L = fork length) and L1.06, mean and maximum aggressive radius were proportional to L1.24 and L1.06, respectively. Territory area (cm2) increased with increasint body length (cm) of brook charr (log10 area= 2.48 log10 length + 0.95). -from Authors

dc:title: Inter-related age-dependent patterns of ecology and behaviour in a population of silvereyes (Aves: Zosteropidae)
dc:creator: Catterall C.P.
dc:description: The winter pattern of ecological differences between adults and juveniles was examined in the population of Zosterops lateralis chlorocephala on Heron Island, Great Barrier Reef. Adults were more likely than juveniles to survive over winter. Adults and juveniles tended to segregate into different habitats. Adults were more likely than juveniles to use the preferred breeding habitat (Pisonia forest) in winter. Adults ranged over smaller areas, and were less likely to join foraging flocks. Adults were socially dominant to juveniles, and were more discriminating in their defence of fig trees and figs, which were common in the clearings and edges of the Pisonia forest. Adults obtained large insects at a higher rate than juveniles, both because they were more skilled at capturing them within most plant types, and because they foraged preferentially in plant types that provided most large insects. Adults consequently had higher daily rates of energy intake than juveniles. Adults and juveniles each behave in ways that would maximize individual survival or future reproduction. -from Authors

dc:title: The trade-off between offspring number and quality in the great tit Parus major
dc:creator: Smith H.G.
dc:description: Nestling mass, wing length and tarsus length were inversely related to brood size. Hatching data also affected nestling growth, but its effect differed between years. Intrabrood variability in nestling size increased with brood size. Nestling survival was inversely related to brood size. Small nestlings suffered higher mortality than large ones. Fledgling survival to autumn and to the following breeding season was also inversely related to brood size; fledglings from reduced broods survived better than those from control broods, which in turn survived better than fledglings from enlarged broods. This resulted in the most productive category being the control broods. Survival of fledglings increased with their size as nestlings and decreased with hatching date. Proportionally more males survived in enlarged than in reduced broods. Dispersal distance of juveniles was not affected by brood size, size as nestling or hatching date; it was affected by sex. -from Authors

dc:title: Extra loads and foraging life span in honeybee workers
dc:creator: Wolf T.J.
dc:description: Only excessive work loads will eventually lead to a reduction in the duration of the foraging career. Moderate variations close to work loads normally adopted by the foragers seem to have little effect. This result vindicates the existence of a survival cost to foraging activity, but suggests a non-trivial dependency in Apis mellifera. -from Authors

dc:title: Mechanisms responsible for population regulation in young migratory trout, Salmo trutta. I. The critical time for survival
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: A 22 yr study of migratory trout in Black Brows Beck (English Lake District) showed that population density is regulated chiefly by density-dependent survival in the early life-stages. Survival appeared to be negatively density-dependent in the 1st spring and positively density-dependent in the 1st summer of the life cycle, but more frequent sampling over 87 yr revealed that this puzzling reversal was simply the result of infrequent sampling. There was a critical survival time (CT days after fry emergence) that varied between year-classes (range 33-70 days) and was inversely density-dependent on egg density; survivor density and loss-rates were strongly density-dependent on egg density before CT, but proportionate survival with stable loss-rates occurred after CT. The sample variance to mean relationship for the frequent samples followed Taylor's Power Function. One important mechanism regulating the trout population is the time taken to reach a critical point in the early stages of the life cycle, the critical survival time. A new model for population regulation, incorporating CT, was developed and shown to be related to the dome-shaped, stock-recruitment model (Ricker curve) used in the long-term study. -from Author

dc:title: Population regulation in the wood mouse, Apodemus sylvaticus. II. Density dependence in spatial distribution and reproduction
dc:creator: Montgomery W.
dc:description: The pattern of dispersion of adult males and juveniles and the overall population, was aggregated throughout the 33 month study. Aggregation of juveniles was most marked when they first appeared in the trappable population. Adult females were generally aggregated but were distributed randomly across 40 grids during the latter half of the breeding seasons. Dispersion of reproductively active females was less heterogeneous than that of overwintered females in June of 2 of the 3 breeding seasons. There was a high level of correlation between trapping sessions in the number of individuals per grid. Spatial variation in woodland habitat quality may have an important influence on the spatial variation in abundance of wood mice. Mean instantaneous rate of population change per week varied considerably between grids although mean values fluctuated positively with overall population size. Sex differences in rates of population change were inconsistent. There were negative relationships between instantaneous rates of population change and overall abundance throughout all annual cycles of abundance. Spatial density dependence was most consistent within subdivisions of the population. During late spring, summer and autumn, spatial density dependence was evident in reducing female reproductive activity and recruitment of young. Spatial density dependence in reproduction is potentially the major density-dependent process during periods when numbers normally increase and must have an overall effect on population size. Density dependence in the absence of reproduction and a decrease in overall population size, was probably due to differential rates of dispersal which redistribute both males and females relative to resources such as food. -from Author

dc:title: Moorland beetle communities on limestone "habitat islands'. I. Isolation, invasion and local species diversity in carabids and staphylinids
dc:creator: Bauer L.
dc:description: Multivariate analysis of data from the Moor House National Nature Reserve, Cumbria, revealed marked variation in fauna composition between habitats, with species richness and diversity being significantly higher on limestone grassland than on blanket peat. Similarity levels between faunas from the limestone and peat habitats were negatively correlated with size of the limestone outcrop. Species were categorized by preferred habitat type, as Settled (Limestone, Peat, Widespread and Vagrant) and Nomadic. Data from the Tailbridge Hill transect across a limestone grassland-blanket peat interface indicated an intermingling of Limestone and Peat species at the habitat boundary. Dwindling numbers of species were found up to 100 m onto habitats adjacent to their own. On the Moor House outcrops (2.6-21.0 m in diameter) Peat species averaged 45% (carabid) and 31% (staphylinid) of all species recorded at the centre of the site. This proportion was inversely correlated with the size (or radius) of the site for individual outcrops. Limestone species taken on the outcrops showed a positive species-area relationship, in keeping with island biogeographical theory. Size, mobility and the relative abundance of Limestone and Peat species on the moor were instrumental in producing the overall negative carabid, but positive staphylinid species-area relationships observed on the outcrops. -from Author

dc:title: Temporal patterns in the herbivorous insects of bracken: a test of community predictability
dc:creator: Lawton J.
dc:description: Data on abundance and seasonal phenology of herbivorous insects feeding upon Pteridium aquilinum at Skipwith Common, N Yorkshire in 1980-86 were used to determine the temporal predictability of this assemblage on an open site and on an adjacent woodland site. There were 17 species on the open site, plus pooled data on 2 genera each with 2 species, and 1 genus with 3 species: 20 taxa in all. The woodland site held 15 species, plus the same pooled genera: 18 taxa in all. In both habitats taxonomic composition, and relative mean peak and total seasonal abundances per frond for each species are all conserved across years. Species have also tended to enter the community in a predictable sequence each year, more so on the open site than in the woodland. Populations appear to be subject to density-dependent control, and therefore the community has a reasonably predictable structure, but it is not saturated with species and interspecific competition is unimportant. -from Authors

dc:title: Factors affecting the survival of barnacle geese on migration from the breeding grounds
dc:creator: Owen M.
dc:description: The survival of 1594 adult, 153 yearling and 439 young barnacle geese Branta leucopsis between the breeding area in Svalbard and the wintering area in Scotland was determined by individual marking in 1986. Annual resighting rates of birds alove and ringed is >95% annually; the non-sighting of a bird in 2 consecutive years is a good indication of its death. Birds were caught in 7 different parts of the breeding area; there were highly significant differences in body mass and moult stage of adults, and in the age and body mass of goslings, between areas. On arrival in Scotland, after an early onset of winter in Svalbard in 1986, paired adult geese were in poor body condition; the poorest of the 8 yr for which data are available. Gosling survival was related to age and body mass. The effect of age was not as great. Females returning to Scotland with broods were heavier than those that had nested (brood patch present) but had no young in winter. This population has recently shown a density-dependent decline in recruitment. Despite the fact that density-related factors had acted earlier in the breeding cycle, competition between families on the rearing areas still resulted in a reduction in recruitment through mortality of young on migration; the density effect was magnified by early onset of winter in 1986. Losses on autumn migration probably represent a substantial proportion of first-year mortality in those species that undertake long migrations without the opportunity of feeding in transit. -from Authors

dc:title: Guild structure in the British arboreal arthropods: is it stable and predictable?
dc:creator: Cornell H.
dc:description: British arboreal arthropods were cross-classified into 4 guild and 15 taxonomic categories, examined for patterns of variation among 28 tree species and analysed in relation to relevant host tree attributes; both varied widely. The proportion of species in the "chewers' guild increased on more abundant, taxonomically related hosts with 46% of guild variation explained by these attributes. Other tested attributes had no effect on this guild, and sap-feeders, leaf-miners and gall-formers were either marginally or not at all influenced by any host attribute. Neither evergreeness nor palatability accounted for any residual guild variation. Guilds increased or decreased in richness independently of one another except that sap-feeders and chewers guilds increased in parallel. There was little tendency for tree species having similar guild structures to have similar taxonomic structures, ie patterns of guild and taxonomic variation are too complex to be ranked on a single scale. However, particularly large or small guilds on single tree species tended to contain at least one particularly large or small taxon as well, indicating that outsized guilds resulted from the presence of outsized taxa rather than a uniform swelling or shrinkage of all taxa in a guild. Most of this pattern occurred in the leaf-miners and gall-formers which appeared to be less saturated than the chewers and sap-feeders. Other than this, "outsized' taxa appeared idiosyncratically and unpredictably across all guilds, host trees and taxonomic groups. The large amount of unexplained guild variation in this system suggests that the stable predictable guild structures proposed for other faunas are not mirrored here. Instead, the linkage between outsized taxa and guilds suggests a strong historical component contributing to the functional structure in this fauna. -Authors

dc:title: Body weight, longevity and reproductive success in red squirrels (Sciurus vulgaris)
dc:creator: Wauters L.
dc:description: Survival was positively correlated with body weight in the 2nd winter of life, independent of body length. Females weighing <300 g did not come into oestrus. Female body weight and dominance were the best predictors of fertility. In coniferous habitat, body weight when lactating and the difference in weight over the lactation period predicted success in raising offspring. In deciduous habitat body weight was the best predictor, while the probability of having young was negatively influenced by body length and age. In coniferous woodland, both body weight and longevity were significantly correlated with lifetime reproductive success of females. In deciduous woodland, only body weight had a significant effect due to early breeding in some females with poor survival. Body length was weakly correlated with habitat quality, but there was a strong effect of habitat quality on body weight. Large squirrels settled in areas with the best seed-crop, and gained more weight than those that settled in areas with a poorer seed-crop. -from Authors

dc:title: Nest-failure and the evolution of hatching asynchrony in the least flycatcher
dc:creator: Briskie J.
dc:description: Nest survival rates were examined in a population of Empidonax minimus in Manitoba. Hatching within flycatcher clutches was asynchronous; mean hatching spread increased from 26.4 h in clutches of 3 to 45.8 h in clutches of 5. Hatching sequence did not affect growth rate or yearly post-fledging survival. Brood reduction from starvation occurred in only 1 nest (2.2%). In contrast to partial brood loss, only 38% of nests successfully fledged at least 1 young; predation of the nest contents accounted for 83% of nest failures. Daily survival probabilities of nests were lowest during laying and highest just before fledging. Observed hatching spreads were significantly less than predicted by the nest failure hypothesis. In all clutch sizes, fledgling productivity would have been maximized by initiating incubation on the first-laid egg. Results did not support the nest failure hypothesis. Several factors that might place constraints upon optimizing hatching asynchrony in order to minimize predation are suggested. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of the cooperatively breeding Galapagos mockingbird, Nesomimus parvulus, in a climatically variable environment
dc:creator: Curry R.
dc:description: Studied the demography of Galapagos mockingbird, a group territorial and cooperatively breeding species, on Isla Genovesa over 1978-88, a period that included 7 yr with moderate rainfall, 2 extremely wet years when El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events occurred, and 2 drought years. Annual survival of adults (mean 6%) was high during average conditions but lower in both drought years and during an epizootic. Males survived slightly better than females. Survival did not vary with age among adults, but survival of juveniles was lower (mean 35%) and twice as variable as adult survival. Mockingbirds bred in response to rainfall, producing up to 5.2 fledglings per breeding female each season (mean 2.3). Clutch size, number of clutches and total production of fledglings increased in wet years. Helpers attended 34% of all nests and increased production of fledglings by 19%. Differential mortality produced variation in the adult sex ratio. Breeding by males was constrained by the relative scarcity of females, and the proportion of males acting as helpers varied correspondingly because non-breeding males most often helped. The proportion of females breeding did not vary with adult sex ratio, because non-breeding males most often helped. The proportion of females breeding did not vary with adult sex ratio, because polygyny occurred in 2 yr when females predominated, and most of the few females that helped also bred. Variation in natality and survival caused substantial variation in population density, but the density of breeders remained relatively constant (CV=21%) compared to density of non-breeders (CV=93%). Group territories, defended year-round, filled all available habitat throughout virtually the entire study. Group size averaged 4.2 adults, with up to 4 breeding females in each group. Groups were larger and plural groups more frequent in years when density was high and when yearlings predominated in the population; 67% of yearlings remained in their natal territories, where 47% of females and 62% of males also first bred. Climatic variation influences mockingbird social organization mainly through its effects on natality and survivorship, which indirectly influence the population's density, age structure, and sex composition. Plural breeding is maintained in this species because climatically-induced demographic variation favours the tendency of young birds to breed without establishing independent territories. -Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of a declining swallow Hirundo rustica population
dc:creator: Moller A.
dc:description: At Kraghede, Denmark, similar environmental factors affected several breeding parameters simultaneously. Egg mortality of 1st clutches was positively correlated with inability to realize maximum egg production in 2nd clutches. Egg mortality of 2nd clutches was positively correlated with nestling mortality of 2nd clutches. Clutch size reduction of 1st clutches was negatively correlated with nestling mortality. Winter mortality either during migration or in the South African winter quarters was the major cause of death. Breeding densities were directly proportional to the size of the post-breeding population during the previous breeding season. Winter mortality was density-independent, but strongly related to environmental factors in the winter quaters. Inability to realize maximum egg production was density-dependent during both 1st and 2nd clutches. Clutch size reduction due to inability of all individuals to lay a 2nd clutch was density-independent. Nestling mortality during the 1st clutch, but not during the 2nd clutch, was negatively density-dependent. - from Author

dc:title: Population dynamics of the viburnum whitefly (Aleurotrachelus jelinekii)
dc:creator: Southwood T.R.E.
dc:description: Sixteen generations of life-table data from viburnum whitefly on Viburnum tinus at Silwood Park, Berkshire are analysed using key factor analysis. This identifies the difference between the potential and observed numbers of eggs laid in any generation (koa) as the key factor mainly responsible for population change between generations. The analysis also reveals clear signs of koa being density-dependent, and falling into 2 distinct relationships depending on the density of potential eggs per leaf. A simple model of the whitefly population on one bush study, based on this analysis, predicts alternative stable equilibria, which are in accord with the observed populations. Additional density dependence is detected from the analysis of a more detailed set of data on the leaf-to-leaf survival from egg to adult stages. This density dependence tends to shift from a direct relationship in years of relatively low whitefly density to inverse density dependence when total whitefly densities are high. A more detailed model of the whitefly dynamics is developed assuming a population in which the adults distribute their eggs from leaf to leaf according to a negative binomial distribution with the degree of clumping inversely related to population size. The rapid increase and subsequent decline in whitefly densities over 14 yr is discussed in the light of evidence connecting the population increase to changes in the amino acid concentration in the leaves. Viburnum whitefly and its host-plant are both introduced species in S England and are at the edge of their geographical range. Several features of the whitefly dynamics may result from this. Thus, the populations suffer little from natural enemies, are sensitive to climatic disturbance and show a slow rate of increase thereafter. -from Authors

dc:title: Habitat-specific growth and fitness in carrion crows (Corvus corone corone)
dc:creator: Richner H.
dc:description: Two populations of carrion crows were studied, one in an urban and another in an agricultural environment in SW Switzerland. Chicks in the urban habitat gain weight more slowly, take longer to reach fledging weight and are significantly lighter at fledging than chicks in the agricultural habitat. For the weight curves, chicks in the urban habitat show significantly lower values for both parameters a and k of the logistic equation. Tarsus growth is slower for chicks in the urban habitat, but in contrast to weight gain, growth of tarsus is not prolonged. For tarsus growth the parameter k is identical in the 2 habitats, but urban chicks show significantly lower values for the parameter a. Tarsus length is fixed by the age of fledging. Chicks in the urban habitat have shorter tarsi at fledging. Growth of wing is slower in the urban habitat. Tarsus length of territory-holding adults was measured in both habitats and a critical minimum size for territory acquisition empirically established. Of all fledglings raised in the urban habitat, 79% fall below this critical size and will therefore be unable to acquire a territory and thus be excluded from breeding; only 24% of fledglings raised in the agricultural habitat will be excluded. Successful parents in the agricultural habitat fledge, on average, 2.7 chicks per year, parents in the urban habitat 1.5 chicks, 36% of all territory holders in the agricultural habitat fledge young, 39% in the urban habitat. Since a much higher percentage of fledged chicks reach the critical body size in the agricultural habitat, these parents reach a Darwinian fitness 5 times higher than parents in the urban habitat. -from Author

dc:title: A population study in Jamaica on the gall-midge Asphondylia boerhaaviae: a contribution to spatial dynamics
dc:creator: Freeman B.
dc:description: Asphondylia boerhaaviae produces galls in the flower buds of 3 plant species belonging to the Nyctaginaceae in Jamaica. Boerhavia diffusa contained the great majority of the midge's population. Plants were inspected for galls throughout Jamaica. There were 2 separate populations whose locations changed little, associated with semi-urban areas in which the rainfall was <1500 mm yr-1. Food plants were limited to altitudes below 800 m and the midge to below 600 m. Mortality and fecundity varied little with altitude. One egg is laid per bud and all development occurs within the gall. Fecundity was 98.8±11.2 (mean ±95% CL). The proportion of females at emergence was 0.505. Developmental mortality was 74.6%. Parasitization by chalcidoid wasps comprised 60.6% of this mortality. A cyclic budget showed the pre-reproductive loss of adult females was 92% (k3=1.09), probably largely due to the failure of dispersing females to find new food plants. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal and individual variation in the production of offspring in the Ural owl Strix uralensis
dc:creator: Pietiainen H.
dc:description: Studied a population of Ural owls in S Finland in 1977-88, classifying the breeding seasons into poor, intermediate and good according to winter food supply and winter severity. Number of pairs varied from 29-85; each year 12-87% of them bred. In good years 75% of the pairs bred, in intermediate years 70% and in poor years 21%. Breeding females laid 2-7 eggs per clutch. Mean clutch size varied from 2.22 ± 0.47 eggs in poor years through 3.22 ± 0.84 in intermediate years to 3.98 ± 1.15 in good years. The clutch size decreased by 0.07 eggs per day with advancing laying date. The model for the seasonal decline in clutch size explained 80% of the variation in mean yearly clutch sizes. For all clutches, 21.7% of eggs failed to hatch, and 4.3% of hatched young died in the nest. Brood size varied from 1.17 ± 1.07 to 3.21 ± 1.47, and 81% of the variation in brood size was explained by variation in clutch size. Production of offspring per pair per year varied nearly 16-fold from 0.15 ± 0.51 to 2.38 ± 1.90. In poor years Ural owls produced 0.32 young per pair, in intermediate years 1.43 and in good years 2.11. Within clutch-size classes, number of young did not vary between year-quality classes. Laying date had a significant between-female variance component of 20%, but the variance component for clutch size was only 1%. The 51 females assumed to have started and ended their reproductive life during the study produced on average 7.7 ± 5.7 (range 0-18) young during their life (mean 4.5 ± 2.6, range 1-11 breeding seasons). Number of offspring increased by 2.01 for every year the females could persist in the breeding population. -from Author

dc:title: Phenotypic adaptation and natural selection in the wild rabbit, Oryctolagus cuniculus, in Australia
dc:creator: Williams C.
dc:description: Populations of the introduced European wild rabbit living in different climatic regions of Australia have adapted in body shape relevant to thermoregulation, mainly by phenotypic response to ambient temperature experienced during growth. The populations have diverged also genetically, probably by natural selection and possibly also as a result of founder effects. Rabbits reared in higher ambient temperature grew a leaner body core and longer ears. The size of the ears differed adaptively among regional field populations, being longer in warmer climates, apparently because genetic differences interacted with phenotypic responses to heat. The pinnae have thermoregulatory functions and responded phenotypically to ambient temperature during growth in two generations. In contrast, the pes lack of thermoregulatory role and grew independently of ambient temperature, but responded to other environmental factors. -from Authors

dc:title: Effect of a major predator on grouping of an orb-weaving spider
dc:creator: Spiller D.
dc:description: Tested the hypothesis that grouping in Metepeira datona functions to reduce predation by lizards: colony size (number of individuals within a communal web) should be larger where lizards are present than where lizards are absent. Colony sizes ranged from 1-34 individuals. About 50% of the total individuals were colonial (colony size ≥2). Colony-size distributions on islands with and without lizards were not significantly different in any year. Mean colony size, adjusted for total number of spiders (analysis of covariance), was not significantly larger on lizard islands. Overall, there was no substantial evidence that coloniality functions to reduce lizard predation. -from Authors

dc:title: Hibernal ecology of the pipistrelle bat: energy expenditure, water requirements and mass loss, implications for survival and the function of winter emergence flights
dc:creator: Speakman J.
dc:description: Mass change in hibernating Pipistrellus pipistrellus was independent of the mass at the start of each period. Mass losses >1 g in bats with an initial mass <5.5 g were fatal. A critical mass of 4.0 g was identified at, or below, which female bats had to increase mass to survive. Food intake was inversely related to mean mass change. The daily energy requirement when relying exclusively on body reserves, amounted to 0.93 kJ day-1. When all the energy was obtained from food, the requirement was 5.5 kJ day-1. Direct estimates of the energy demand of bats in torpor at 4°C amounted to 0.45 kJ day-1. The difference in these estimates reflects differing times spent in torpor. By inference, bats relying exclusively on their own reserves spent only 5-20 min of each day out of torpor compared with >2 h for bats relying on ingested food. Free-water requirements averaged 0.19 ml day-1. Intake of free water was independent of food intake even though the food consisted of 59% water. Female bats weighing >4.2 g would die of dehydration sooner than of starvation whilst the converse is true at lower masses. For the whole of hibernation, female pipistrelle bats exceed this mass. The primary function of winter emergence in this species is therefore to drink. -from Authors

dc:title: Hatching asynchrony in European bee-eaters Merops apiaster
dc:creator: Lessells C.M.
dc:description: In S France, nestling ages within broods range over 2-9 days. The last chick to leave fledges c 32 days after the first chick hatches and 28 days after the last, at an age independent of hatching asynchrony. Hatching asynchrony results from a progressive increase in incubation during laying. Hatching asynchrony is not correlated with clutch size, date of breeding or age of the mother, but with incubation period of the 1st egg; synchrony carries the cost of delayed hatching of this egg. Rate of nestling provisioning peaks 3 wk after hatching and then declines and, during the decline, younger chicks at one nest received less food for their age than older siblings. Chicks aged 3-4 wk at one nest could monopolize food by their position in the nest burrow, but there was no dominance hierarchy in behaviour controlling access to food. Nestling mortality falls disporportionately on small chicks at a colony with high mortality and slow chick growth, but subsequent recruitment does not depend on position in the brood size hierarchy. The pattern of nestling growth and mortality in good and poor conditions supports the brood-reduction hypothesis for the evolution of hatching asynchrony; but the relative timing of laying, hatching and fledging of individual eggs is also consistent with the hurry-up and nest-failure hypotheses. -from Authors

dc:title: Density independence in space and inconsistent temporal relationships for host mortality caused by a fairyfly parasitoid
dc:creator: Strong D.
dc:description: Parasitism by Anagrus delicatus (Hymenoptera: Mymaridae) of eggs of Prokelisia marginata (Homoptera: Delphacidae) was studied over 7 spatial scales: subleaves (roughly the scale of individual host clutches), leaves, plants, islet sides, entire islets composed of pure stands of the host-plant cordgrass Spartina alterniflora, and an archipelago of 4 islets. Ten generations of the parasitoid and 5 of the host, are spanned by the 29 weekly sampling periods, from early spring through early winter. No relationship between parasitism rate and host densities occurred on any spatial scale during the c5 parasitoid generations of spring and summer. Host density remained <10 eggs per leaf in spring and summer. Then, during the autumn, inversely density-dependent cycles in parasitism rate occurred while host population fluctuated to as high as 75 eggs per leaf. Spatially within sampling periods, non-zero regressions between parasitism rate and host density on all scales were little more frequent than expected by type I statistical error. The theoretical expectation of spatial density dependence follows most readily from the assumption that parasitoids maximize their oviposition rate in time. Anagrus delicatus does not behave as if it were maximizing this rate; ovipositing females frequently quit host clutches after parasitizing only a small fraction of the eggs. Females disperse away from incompletely parasitized host clutches before laying a substantial fraction of their own eggs. Females may pass up local opportunities in favour of "spreading risk' in space. Risks include spiders concentrated on the scale of individual host-plants and local extinction during winter from unusually cold spells in this subtropical habitat. -from Author

dc:title: Constraints on hatching asynchrony and egg size in pied flycatchers
dc:creator: Slagsvold T.
dc:description: It was predicted from 5 current hypotheses that asynchronous hatchings in Ficedula hypoleuca should be found among "low quality' females. The contrary was found, as adjudged by female age and initial clutch size. Hatching asynchrony was positively correlated with the air temperature during the egg-laying period, and was greater in deciduous than in coniferous woodland. Asynchronous hatching may be advantageous but is limited by energetic constraints on the start of incubation. Egg size increased with laying order, but this did not seem to be an ultimate adjustment to clutch size, or to the degree of hatching spread. Observed patterns of egg-size variation seem to be best explained by proximate constraints on egg formation. -from Authors

dc:title: Spatial coexistence of mussel-associated, free-ranging polychaetes in a subtropical intertidal habitat
dc:creator: Tokeshi M.
dc:description: Pseudonereis gallapagensis and Halosydna johnsoni coexist in the mussel bed habitat of a rocky shore in Peru. There are 2 mussel beds: the Semimytilus algosus bed which extends widely between the low and mid intertidal, and the Perumytilus purpuratus bed which occurs as a narrow band in the mid-high intertidal. Despite seasonal fluctuations in total population density, the density of large polychaete individuals was stable and the total population biomass was of similar magnitude in the 2 species. Size-frequency distributions followed a similar pattern through the year, with recruitment of young seen in the austral spring. Different size groups of Halosydna had similar levels of dispersion throughout the year, but Pseudonereis showed a wide variation in dispersion among size groups, with large sizes demonstrating more strongly aggregated patterns. Overlap in space between the species was smaller than that within either of the species. Interspecifically, the pair involving larger size groups tended to have lower values of spatial overlap. The Semimytilus bed supported more population biomass of both polychaete species than the Perumytilus bed, though the density of Pseudonereis was not significantly different between the 2 habitats. Large individuals (of Pseudonereis, in particular) were scarce in the Perumytilus bed. The mussel bed is a complex habitat with varying sizes of interstitial space, which is considered to buffer competitive interactions between individuals of different mobility and body sizes and to enhance coexistence of the free-ranging polychaetes. from Authors

dc:title: Seeing the wood for the trees: detecting density dependence from existing life-table studies
dc:creator: Hassell M.P.
dc:description: Analysis of 63 life-table studies involving 58 insect species by Stiling (1988) (see 89L/02762) is re-examined, in particular questioning the conclusion that the apparent absence of density-dependent processes in more than half of the studies meaningfully reflects the prevalence of such processes in natural systems. The proportion of studies in which density dependence was detected by the original authors increases markedly with the number of generations available for analysis, a pattern particularly clear from the 28 life-tables available for univoltine insects. That density dependence was detected in a large proportion of the studies lasting for more than a few generations is an encouraging result considering the inadequacies in current methods for detecting the different types of density dependence that can act on insect populations. -Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of cinnabar moth and ragwort in grassland
dc:creator: Crawley M.
dc:description: Population densities of Senecio jacobaea (Compositae) and Tyria jacobaeae (Arctiidae) were studied in mesic grasslands at Silwood Park, Berkshire, 1981-1988. The host plant fluctuated 13-fold in population density; the insect fluctuated 8-fold in adult female density and 9-fold in egg batch density. Realized fecundity of cinnabar moth was density-independent at 3.3 egg batches per female, <67% of potential fecundity based on pupal dissection. Larval survival depended on the ragwort shoot biomass available at oviposition and the mean size and spacing of plants; emigration began earlier from small plants, and density-dependent mortality occurred during dispersal. Survival was low when spring was late and plants were small at oviposition, when egg batch density was high and fewer plants were available during larval dispersal, and after years of high flowering when the larger, flowering rosettes died back. Plant recruitment was not related to flower production or moth abundance in the previous year, and may be microsite limited. Weather and rabbit Oryctolagus cuniculus disturbance influenced plant recruitment from seed and from perennating rootstocks of large plants. Defoliation did not increase plant death rate. Seedling abundance did not peak following years of peak ragwort seed production. The key factors of ragwort-cinnabar moth interaction appeared to be autumn and spring rainfall and the timing of spring growth. Autumn and spring rains encouraged ragwort growth, and caused insect abundance to peak 1 yr after host biomass. Early spring growth, and large plants at egg-laying, reduced larval competition. The interaction between the plant and herbivore is asymmetric. As in other plant communities, cinnabar moth is food-limited, but in mesic grasslands ragwort biomass is not herbivore-limited, and the plant behaves as an iteroparous perennial. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal distribution patterns of oribatid mites (Acari: Cryptostigmata) in a forest ecosystem
dc:creator: Stamou G.P.
dc:description: The phenology of oribatid mites was studied on Mt Holomon in Greece. The spatial distribution of adults within microsites was related to the distribution of grass species. Achipteria holomonensis was most numerous during autumn-winter, Scheloribates cf. latipes during winter and summer and Eremaeus balcanicus during summer-autumn. -from Authors

dc:title: Survival of eggs in the gypsy moth Lymantria dispar. I. Predation by birds
dc:creator: Higashiura Y.
dc:description: In Hokkaido, Japan, birds, mainly nuthatches Sitta europaea, attacked the egg masses particularly during the snowy season, February and early March. Snowfalls increased predation frequency. The geometric mean predation rate was 38.8% over the period. Predation fluctuated temporally, involving 4-71% of all egg masses. A density-dependent trend was apparently observed during the later 5 winters, but the trend was ambiguous in spatial density in each of 5 winters. During the snowy season, birds shifted their foraging sites downward, and primarily attacked egg masses on the lower part of tree trunks above the snow. -from Author

dc:title: Mammalian biomass in an African equatorial rain forest
dc:creator: Prins H.H.T.
dc:description: In a lowland rain forest in SW Gabon, the total biomass of mammals individually weighing >500 g was c 1050 kg km2. Elephant Loxodonta africana cyclotis and primates made up the bulk of the biomass (52 and 25% of the herbivores, respectively). African buffalo Syncerus caffer nanus were absent in primary forest but present in secondary forest. The density of African elephant in primary forest was low (0.08 individuals km-2), in young secondary forest intermediate (0.29), and highest in old secondary forest (0.88). -from Authors

dc:title: The origin of long-term cohort differences in the distribution of greater flamingos Phoenicopterus ruber roseus in winter
dc:creator: Green R.
dc:description: Data revealed consistent differences beetween cohorts in the relative proportions of birds (ringed as chicks in France) wintering in Tunisia and Spain. Faithfulness of individuals to wintering areas used in the 1st and 2nd winters of life persisted until at least the 7th winter. Differences between cohorts in the proportion of flamingos crossing the Mediterranean Sea to Tunisia rather than wintering in Spain were correlated with the prevalence of following winds in the direction of this destination in the birds' first autumn. -from Authors

dc:title: Moorland beetle communities on limestone "habitat islands'. II. Flight activity, and its influence on local staphylinid diversity
dc:creator: Bauer L.
dc:description: Some 2/3 of all staphylinid species taken on the Moor House National Nature Reserve, Cumbria, were capable of flight. Flight occurred throughout the field season, peaking in late spring and at the end of the summer. Most flight activity occurred in Nomadic species which depend upon flight for the successful exploitation of patchy and transient resources such as sheep dung. Settled species exploiting relatively predictable resources associated with their peat and grassland habitats flew less. Of the Settled species, those living in peat showed least flight activity. In their expansive and continuous habitat flight is not necessary between subpopulations. Limestone species flew more than expected for the relative permanence and stability of their habitat. Flightless species were limited to limestone outcrops large enough to support stable populations. Small colonies of flying species survived by regular dispersal between outcrops, and by receiving airborne immigrants from lowland grasslands to the west. Both flightless and flying Limestone species recorded on the outcrops had a positive species-area relationship consistent with island biogeographical theory. Higher species richness on the larger outcrops is attributed to the positive influences of area per se and to increased habitat heterogeneity. For flying species, the greater interception area presented to immigrants by a larger outcrop may also be a contributing factor. As many as 59% of all staphylinid species recorded at Moor House may have been vagrants carried into the Reserve as aerial plankton, and thus not truly representative of the habitat on which they were taken. -from Author

dc:title: Territorial feeding and colonial breeding are not mutually exclusive: the case of the grey heron (Ardea cinerea)
dc:creator: Marion L.
dc:description: At Grand-Lieu Lake, France, each radio-tracked grey heron had a limited foraging area, which was used almost exclusively (99% of the breeding trips), between 2-38 km from the colony. Each individual area contained 5-42 watching posts, clumped on 1, 2 or 3 sites separated from each other by >3 km. Most herons had a single feeding site (mean distance from the colony=20 km) and were territorial. A few birds had several sites and were non-territorial; these feeding sites were further from the colony or were poor feeding sites. Certain neutral areas not appropriated by single birds were used by all birds: poor areas, rich but unpredictable areas, or non-appropriable areas. Non-territorial birds used them more than territorial birds do, but also parasitized temporarily vacant territories, perhaps because they had to fly further to their own feeding sites. This "individual feeding territorial/colonial breeding system' combines 2 strategies that were largely considered mutually exclusive in ecology because they were considered as evolving in response to opposing selection pressures. -from Author

dc:title: Causes and consequences of natal dispersal in the marsh tit, Parus palustris
dc:creator: Nilsson J.A.
dc:description: Dispersal distance, measured as the number of territories between place of birth and place of first breeding, was analysed within and between sexes in juvenile marsh tits in relation to factors potentially caiusing variation in dispersal pattern. Dispersal distance of males was positively influenced by both population density and hatching date. In females, dispersal distance were positively related to population density, number of siblings and wing length. Early-hatched females dispersed further than those hatched in the middle of the season. Dispersal distance in females was positively related to the number of recruits among their offspring. Females surviving for more >1 breeding season had dispersed further as juveniles than females breeding only once. In males, dispersal distance did not affect survival or breeding success. Males are severely affected by the density of already established individuals, and have no time to choose flock ranges according to quality. Thus, males try to become established as soon as possible after independence. Late-hatched males disperse further and are less successful at establishing themselves than early-hatched males. Females, especially those hatched early, more easily become established and can afford to monitor several flock ranges and to be selective in their choice of flock range. This selectivity results in long dispersal distances for early-hatched females and a high lifetime reproductive success for long dispersers. -Author

dc:title: Latitudinal variation in life-history characteristics of sea-run migrant brown trout Salmo trutta
dc:creator: L'abee-Lund J.
dc:description: Compared life-history characteristics of sea-run migrating brown trout in a latitudinal gradient from 58-70°N in Norway in order to reveal biogeographic trends in life-history characters. The annual length increment of brown trout during the 2nd year in fresh water was significantly, negatively correlated with latitude, and significantly positively correlated with river temperature (days) and length of the growth season (number of days t >4°C). The annual length increment of brown trout during the 1st year after smolting was significantly, negatively correlated with latitude and significantly, positively correlated with sea temperature. Mean smolt age increased significantly with latitude but decreased significantly with increasing river and sea temperature (days), and length of the growth season in the river. Mean smolt size increased significantly with latitude, but decreased significantly with increasing sea temperature. Sea age at maturity increased with latitude as did the coefficient of variation of sea age at maturity. Sea age at maturity depends on growth rate at sea. A young age at maturity was observed in the populations where the length increment of immatures at sea was reduced in the second year relative to the 1st year after smolting. The incidence of repeat spawners increased significantly with passable river length and yearly mean water discharge. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific life-history variation in Lymnaea peregra (Gastropoda: Pulmonata). II. Environmental or genetic variance?
dc:creator: Lam P.
dc:description: Comparison of 3 neighbouring populations Lymnaea peregra demonstrated variation in a number of important life-history traits. Reproductive timing showed varying degrees of plasticity in the 3 populations; differences in this trait between populations were genetically determined. Juvenile growth rate, hatchling size, and age at onset of breeding were genetically controlled within some populations. Number of traits showing significant interpopulation and intrapopulation variations decreased from F1 to F2 generations. On a phenotypic basis, time to 1st reproduction was negatively correlated with size at hatching for 1 population. -from Authors

dc:title: Discrete and continuous insect populations in tropical environments
dc:creator: Godfray H.
dc:description: There are several examples in the literature of insect populations in the tropics showing generation cycles with a period of approximately one generation. Nine examples are reviewed where such cycles have been reported from a range of arthropod pest species. The cycles either persist, or tend to die away as the outbreaks decline. Natural enemies are an important cause of mortality and are responsible for driving the cycles. Age-structured population models of host-parasitoid interactions are based on an idealized interaction between a tropical lepidopteran and its specific parasitoid. The host population is assumed to be made up of pre-parasitism, susceptible, post-parasitism and adult reproductive stages while the parasitoid population comprises immature and adult searching stages. An extension of the simulation model developed by Godfray & Hassell (1987) and a time-delayed differential equation model using the "lumped' age-class techniques of R. M. Nisbet & W. S. C. Gurney both show that discrete generation cycles are favoured by a parasitoid life cycle 0.5 or 1.5 times that of its host and a relatively short adult reproductive lifespan. Conversely, parasitoids with generation times about the same, or twice as long, as those of their hosts, or with relatively long reproductive lifespans, are more likely to promote continuous generations. -from Authors

dc:title: Age-dependent survival of breeding short-tailed shearwaters Puffinus tenuirostris
dc:creator: Bradley J.S.
dc:description: A small colony of short-tailed shearwater on Fisher Island, Bass Strait, Australia, has been monitored each year since 1947. Shearwaters breeding for the first time had a relatively high rate of mortality. This rate then decreased considerably and remained low for c10 yr before increasing substantially in older birds. Increasing offspring production was associated with a decreasing mortality rate early in a shearwater's breeding career but not in mid-life. Later in its career, higher offspring production was associated with an increasing rate of mortality. -from Authors

dc:title: Breeding dispersal in the collared flycatcher (Ficedula albicollis): possible causes and reproductive consequences
dc:creator: Part T.
dc:description: In a population on the Swedish island of Gotland, females on average moved further than males. Only 8% of males and 2% of females reoccupied their previous nest box. Among females both total failures and reduced number of fledged young were associated with long subsequent movements in yearlings; dispersal of older individuals was not related to previous breeding success. The pattern of breeding dispersal was similar in males but the difference was not significant. Males that remained unpaired throughout the breeding season moved further in the next year than did mated males. There were no differences in breeding dispersal patterns between polygynous and monogamous males, nor between monogamous and secondary females. Occupation of previous nest boxes by breeding tits (Paridae) were significantly correlated with dispersal distances in 2-yr-old males, but not in older males or females. Males breeding for the first time in their natal area subsequently moved shorter distances than males breeding in another area. Females showed no significant differences in dispersal with respect to birth place. The hypothesis is advanced that breeding dispersal distances (to some extent) reflect individual choices among available territories, in that individuals with little and/or bad local experience disperse more because they benefit from exploring more sites before settling than do those with extensive and/or good local experience. -from Authors

dc:title: Population consequences of aggregative movement
dc:creator: Turchin P.
dc:description: Attraction among individuals leads to movement which is biased towards areas of high population density, but aggregations can arise only if mutual attraction is strong enough to dominate the dispersive effect due to random motion. A model is used to define the conditions for formation of an aggregated spatial pattern in homogeneous space. The model is applied to the aggregative movement in Aphis varians. To investigate how spatial inhomogeneity can interact with density-dependent movement, the author considers a population of animals foraging for a patchy resource, eg insect herbivores moving among patches of their host-plants. Gregarious behaviour of herbivores strongly amplifies the effects of patch size on herbivore density. Field studies of the Mexican bean beetle-garden bean (Epilachna varivestis-Phaseolus vulgaris) system provide support for this theoretical prediction. -from Author

dc:title: Effect of size-selective predation by muskrats (Ondatra zibethicus) on a population of unionid clams (Anodonta grandis simpsoniana)
dc:creator: Hanson J.
dc:description: In a small lake in central Alberta muskrats ate almost 37 000 clams, or 3% of the population in 1yr. When expressed as biomass, muskrats ate 677kg of clams, equivalent to 5.8% of the biomass and 31% of the annual production of clams. Muskrat predation was highly size-selective - 86% of the clams eaten were >55mm long compared to 37% for clams in the lake - and had a strong effect on the size structure of the clam population. When all age-classes were combined, the biomass of clams >70mm eaten exceeded the annual production by an amount equivalent to 9.5% of the estimated biomass in the lake. Muskrats ate the fastest growing clams between 3-9yr old. The biomass of large clams in the lake will decline if the observed predation continues. Muskrats ate a large fraction of the reproductive output (glochidia) of the largest clams. Only 6% of the glochidia of clams <70mm long was eaten whereas 21% of the glochidia of clams >70mm long was eatern. -from Authors

dc:title: Aggregation by foraging insect parasitoids in response to local variations in host density: determining the dimensions of a host patch
dc:creator: Rosenheim J.A.
dc:description: Analyses based upon B, the slope of the linear regression of percentage parasitism on host density, are flawed. B is inappropriate due to its dependence upon the variance of host density measurements, and, therefore, upon the nature of the underlying host distribution. An alternative analysis is based upon the correlation coefficient of the same linear regression, calculated over a series of increasing quadrat sizes. The proposed analysis was applied to field data of the foraging behaviour of Argochrysis armilla (Hymenoptera: Chrysididae), a parasitoid of the solitary, ground-nesting wasp, Ammophila dysmica (Hymenoptera: Sphecidae). A. armilla aggregated in areas of high host nest density both during and after nest excavation. Parasitoids responded maximally to host patchiness over areas of 3-50 m2. -from Authors

dc:title: Flower visit consistency in Pieris rapae the cabbage butterfly
dc:creator: Lewis A.
dc:description: Visit consistency, tested by analysis of the likelihood that an encountered flower is the same species as the last flower visited, revealed consistency in visits in non-ovipositing bufferflies. A model of preference is presented in which many preference regimes intermediate between constancy and labile preference are possible. -from Author

dc:title: Development of a foraging model for a field population of the South American sun-star Heliaster helianthus
dc:creator: Tokeshi M.
dc:description: Heliaster helianthus was studied in an intertidal rocky shore habitat in central Peru. The mussel Semimytilus algosus was a predominant prey with an average proportion of 85.5% and 85.7% by number and biomass, respectively. Larger individuals of H. helianthus fed on clumps of S. algosus containing larger mussels, but the biomass distribution of all S. algosus consumed closely resembled that of the natural prey population, except in the smallest predator size-group (≤10.9cm) where small mussels were more strongly represented in the diet. The study suggests that "energy maximization', the core assumption of classic optimal diet choice models, is not relevant to the choice of prey size and meal size in H. helianthus. -from Author

dc:title: Predation and starvation: age-specific mortality in juvenile juncos (Junco phaenotus)
dc:creator: Sullivan K.
dc:description: Death rate in yellow-eyed junco was highest in the 1st year, significantly higher than in adults; 11% of ringed nestlings were found the following spring. Predation was the main cause of death of nestlings and fledglings. Starvation was less important: it was rare for only one nestling in a brood to die, nestling weight was independent of brood size, and survival was independent of weight at fledgings. Starvation was the major mortality factor of recently independent juveniles. Intraspecific competition for limited food may not usually cause differential mortality of age and sex classes but may do so in years with low rainfall and scarce food. -from Author

dc:title: An experimental study of co-evolution between the cuckoo, Cuculus canorus, and its hosts. II. Host egg markings, chick discrimination and general discussion
dc:creator: Davies N.
dc:description: There was no difference in the distinctiveness of egg markings between species that have interacted strongly with cuckoos and species that have not, nor in intra-clutch variation, nor in inter-clutch variation within a species. In Iceland, where they are isolated from cuckoos, the eggs of meadow pipit Anthus pratensis and pied/white wagtail Motacilla alba showed no differences in intra-clutch variation, nor inter-clutch variation, from those in parasitized populations in Britain. Thus there was no evidence that host egg patterns evolve in response to cuckoos. None of the 4 species tested discriminated against an odd chick (another species) in their nest (chaffinch Fringilla coelebs, reed warbler Acrocephalus scirpaceus, reed bunting Emberiza schoeniclus, dunnock Prunella modularis). Hosts therefore evolve discrimination against odd eggs but not against odd chicks. The variation in rejection of unlike eggs among different species of suitable cuckoo hosts in not related to the current costs or benefits of rejecting cuckoo eggs. The variation represents snap shots in evolutionary time of different -Authors

dc:title: Reproductive inhibition in a short-season population of Peromyscus maniculatus
dc:creator: Lusk S.
dc:description: Tested the hypothesis that overwintered remales inhibit reproduction of young-of-the-year females in Peromyscus maniculatus borealis in the Kananaskis Valley, Alberta. Reproductive inhibition of young females is interpreted as an adaptive, sex-specific response to the presence of adult females. -from Authors

dc:title: The relationship between food supply, reproductive effort and breeding success in arctic terns Sterna paradisaea
dc:creator: Monaghan P.
dc:description: Arctic terns were studied in a successful (Coquet Island, Northumberland) and an unsuccessful (Shetland) breeding colony. During courtship feeding, males in Shetland brought larger fish to their mates than to the birds on Coquet, but the latter brought more energy-rich fish, made more foraging trips per hour and their rate of energy transfer to their mates was higher. There was no difference between the two colonies in clutch or egg size, or in hatching success. During chick-rearing, birds in both areas concentrated on sandeel Ammodytes as prey. In contrast to Coquet, the Shetland birds brough their young a very high proportion of small fish, and lost a high proportion of their large prey to conspecific kleptoparasites; they also foraged at a higher rate and brought less energy per chick per hour. Chicks in Shetland colony grew at a slower rate and the majority died in the first week of life. Breeding success on Coquet was good. In both areas, adults lost weight during the breeding period. The birds on Shetland were lighter than those on Coquet, but their subsequent rate of weight loss was less. During the chick-rearing period on Coquet, birds fledging 2 young remained heavier than those where 1 young died of starvation in the 1st week after hatching. -from Authors

dc:title: An experimental study of co-evolution between the cuckoo, Cuculus canorus, and its hosts. I. Host egg discrimination
dc:creator: Davies N.
dc:description: The nests of 24 species of passerine birds were parasitized experimentally with model cuckoo eggs. Among current favourite hosts, species for which the cuckoo lays a mimetic egg discriminated against model eggs unlike their own (reed warbler Acrocephalus scirpaceus, meadow pipit Anthus pratensis, pied wagtail Motacilla alba yarrellii), while the dunnock Prunella modularis, which is not mimicked, did not discriminate. Other species, suitable as hosts (invertebrate diet, accessible nests) but rarely used by cuckoos, showed just as much rejection of model eggs unlike their own or stronger rejection than the most strongly rejecting of current favourite hosts. Two results suggest that the egg discrimination by suitable hosts has evolved in response to cuckoo parasitism. 1) Species unsuitable as hosts (thus with no history of interaction with cuckoos) mainly showed little if any rejection of model eggs unlike their own; 2) meadow pipits and white wagtails in Iceland, where they are isolated from cockoos, showed significantly less discrimination against eggs unlike their own than in Britain, where they are parasitized. Species with smaller bills suffered greater rejection costs (own eggs damaged) and were more likely to reject model eggs by desertion than species with larger bills, which tended to reject by ejection. Among species suitable as hosts, there was no tendency for smaller-billed species to reject less. Therefore rejection costs influenced the method of rejection but not rejection frequency. -from Authors

dc:title: Environmental and demographic correlates of intraspecific nest parasitism in lesser snow geese Chen caerulescens caerulescens
