dc:creator: Lank D.
dc:description: Intraspecific nest parasitism was the source of 5.3%±0.02 of the goslings hatched annually at the La Perouse Bay snow goose colony near Churchill, Manitoba, between 1969-1986. Yearly values ranged between 1.8-9.3%. Rate of parasitism was low in years when nest-sites were readily available at the start of laying, and high when fewer sites were clear of snow or water. High parasitism rates did not occur in years of high nest failure during laying. This suggests that more parasitism occurs as a response to a lack of suitable nest sites than occurs as a consequence of nest failure. Nest parasitism was higher at times when a higher than average proportion of young birds did not attempt to nest. Nest parasitism had no measurable effect on the hatching success of host eggs. On average, hatching success of parasitic eggs was lower than that of host eggs, primarily due to poor timing of laying by parasites relative to onset of incubation. Due to physiological constraints on total clutch size, nest parasitism in arctic nesting geese is largely a "salvage' female reproductive tactic, used by females that have a low likelihood of nesting successfully. -from Authors

dc:title: Individuals and populations of the bank vole in optimal, suboptimal and insular habitats
dc:creator: Gliwicz J.
dc:description: Clethrionomys glareolus populations were studied in a small forest island, and rich alder forest (both optimal habitats) and small patches of wood (suboptimal habitat) in NE Poland. The island population was treated as a control for dispersal occurring in "open' populations. Young born early in the breeding season in the optimal habitat dispersed soon after weaning into less crowded suboptimal habitat. Young born later in the season did not disperse. The probability of maturing in the year of birth was highest in the suboptimal habitat. Between-habitat differences were largest for young born early in the breeding season. A driving force for post-weaning dispersal may be the much higher probability of maturing early in suboptimal habitats. Later in the season, dispersal ceases because the chances of young maturing are less habitat-dependent. -Author

dc:title: A comparison of great tits' (Parus major) use of time in different daylengths at three European sites
dc:creator: Mace R.
dc:description: Male time budgets were studied at Aracena, S Spain; Wytham Woods, Oxford, England; and Turku, S. Finland. Time spend foraging increased in proportion with the time that the birds were active, but time spent on singing and other display behaviours did not. There does not appear to be conflict between feeding and territorial behaviour in the time budget. Birds breeding further north in longer daylengths spent proportionally more time perching and preening and also roosted earlier with respect to twilight, but they still had a peak of singing activity before dawn. -from Author

dc:title: The reproductive energetics of gentoo (Pygoscelis papua) and macaroni (Eudyptes chrysolophus) penguins at South Georgia
dc:creator: Davis R.
dc:description: Examined energetics throughout the reproduction and moult season, comparing gentoo penguins (inshore feeding, sexually monomorphic, share breeding duties equally) with macaroni penguins (offshore feeding, dimorphic, duties unequally shared). While fasting during courtship and incubation, macaronis (both sexes) and female gentoos had field metabolic rates (FMR) of 4.1 and 3.8 W kg-1, respectively. Male gentoos also spending time at sea had an FMR of 7.5 W kg-1. Male macaroni FMR for fasting while brooding was 3.8 W kg-1. During chick-rearing, gentoo FMR was 6.8 W kg-1 early on, rising to 7.4 W kg-1 later; for macaronis FMR was 13 W kg-1. Estimated energy cost of foraging at sea was 16 and 22 W kg-1 for gentoos and macaronis, respectively. Gentoo and macaroni FMR during moult was 5.3 and 6.7 W kg-2. Over the breeding and moult season, male and female gentoos have total and average daily energy expenditure (DEE) only 1% different, agreeing with expectation for monomorphic species sharing duties equally. Female macaronis (10% smaller than males) have average DEE 9% (17% on a mass-specific basis) greater than males, mainly because they spend more time rearing chicks, involving intensive foraging at sea. However, males spent more days at the colony so over the whole season female energy expenditure is only 3.5% above males. Scaled mass-specific average DEE is 18% greater for macaronis than gentoos, chiefly because of the energy costs of offshore foraging trips. As their breeding and moult season is 20% shorter than gentoos, average absolute DEE is 13% less for macaronis; however, macaroni chick production is only half that of gentoos. -from Authors

dc:title: Genetic divergence in fecundity of Australian wild rabbits Oryctolagus cuniculus
dc:creator: Williams C.
dc:description: Although Australian wild rabbits are descended from one introduction of a few animals, populations in diverse climatic regions differ markedly in reproductive productivity. Two generations of rabbits from 3 climatic zones were compared regarding rates of reproduction under standardized conditions. The dominant factor is environment: rabbits bred at the same rate under standardized conditions. The progeny of these regional groups differed in the number and size of litters produced although under standardized conditions. A genetic component to the difference among regional fecundities is thereby identified. The environment also influences the development of seasonal breeding patterns. -from Authors

dc:title: Urban cat populations compared by season, subhabitat and supplemental feeding
dc:creator: Calhoon R.
dc:description: Population densities of free-ranging Felis catus were compared in 2 contiguous urban subhabitats. One subhabitat, characterized by voluminous, poorly contained refuse, and many abandoned buildings, supported 4.88 ± 0.82 cats ha-1, which differed significantly from the 2.03 ± 0.2 cats ha-1 supported by the other subhabitat (partial refuse containment, few abandoned buildings). Neither season nor supplemental feeding had a significant effect on population density. The distribution of individuals within the study area varied with availability of shelter and was not dependent upon food. -from Authors

dc:title: Experimental analysis of inter- and intraspecific competition in dung beetle communities
dc:creator: Giller P.
dc:description: Competition for bovine dung by dung beetles (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) which tunnel and bury dung beneath the dung pad (paracoprids) was examined using co-occurring species which display contrasting patterns of dung use. The coprine species Catharsius tricornutus and Copris elphenor are large fast burying paracoprids and a pair will bury one dung mass (100-200 g) within 24-48 hr of pad colonization. The onitine Onitis alexis is a large slow burying species that buries dung continuously over many days (400-1000 g) following pad colonization. Strong intraspecific competition for dung was shown by all species at densities >2-4 pairs per pad. At high densities 70-80% of each pad was removed. O. alexis sequestered all buried dung as a brood mass under the pad, and intraspecific competition led to a reduction in the amount of dung buried per pair. As the density of coprine beetles increased and intraspecific competition intensified, increasing proportions of the dung pad were utilized, but decreasing proportions were converted to buried dung. During burial by the coprine species was largely unaffected by the presence of onitine beetles, but amount of dung buried by O. alexis was markedly reduced in the presence of 2-3 pairs of coprine beetles. -from Authors

dc:title: Growth and size variation in contrasting populations of trout Salmo trutta: an experimental study on the role of natural selection
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: Variation in individual fish size was inversely density-dependent for a migratory-trout population in Black Brows Beck and decreased with age for a resident-trout population in Wilfin Beck, Cumbria, NW England. Mean sizes and growth rates in the laboratory were significantly different for trout from different populations and year-classes (1969, 1974). Water temperature and fish weight at the start of the life cycle, but not food, were the chief factors responsible for these differences. Data provided strong evidence that changes in size variation in the field were due to natural (stabilizing) selection. Various indices for selection intensity indicated that it was probably density-dependent in the migratory-trout population (Black Brows Beck) and age-dependent in the resident-trout population (Wilflin Beck). -from Author

dc:title: The performance of an intertidal predator Thais lapillus, in relation to structural heterogeneity
dc:creator: Gosselin L.A.
dc:description: The influence of substratum heterogeneity on the performance (prey selection, predation rate, protection against high temperatures, desiccation and wave action, growth rates, substratum preference) of dogwhelk was examined. Dogwhelks had higher growth rates on heterogeneous than on homogeneous surfaces. Barnacles were of higher quality as prey and varied less in abundance on heterogeneous substrata. Dogwhelks were better protected against wave action on heterogeneous substrata. Dogwhelks strongly preferred heterogeneous substrata, and performance was higher on such substrata -from Authors
